title: Version Control
content:
## Version Control
time to git good.

`git add file.txt` adds the file, it is now  tracked

`git commit -m "My message"` commits the changes

Commits are checkpoints. You can roll back to any one of them.

`git clone sshudson@git.uwaterloo.ca:sshudson/repo`

Clones from the central repository.

`git push`

Pushes your local commits to the remote repository.

`.gitignore` ignores any files that are contained within it.
It's just a plaintext file.
Ignore .o files, things that are created on compilation.

`git rm file1.txt` removes the file from the repo.

`git checkout [git checkpoint or branch] file.txt` recovers file.txt from the git commit

`git checkout .` Will take anything from the last commit, the back step.

`git pull` updates to latest version

`git branch -a` gives you a list of all the branches

`git branch nameOfNew nameOforigin`

`git checkout nameOfNew` , and we're now in the new branch.

To merge a branch:

`git checkout master`
`git pull`
`git merge nameOfBranch`
And then finish merge conflicts.
